content: I was recently medically disqualified from AFROTC for 2 reasons, both of which don't hinder me physically in any way. In March of 2005 I had spinal fusion of more than 2 vertebrae which is disqualifying. However, I have updated my medical records since they were sent in to DoDMERB and gotten a written letter from my orthopedic surgeon that I am cleared for any and all physical activity. I have no pain whatsoever and have healed extremely well. My spine is exactly the same as someone's without titanium rods. I ran varsity track hurdles in high school and have played competitive basketball for years. My PFA score while I was in ROTC last semester was outstanding. I maxed push-ups, sit ups, and was 8 seconds from maxing the 1.5 mi. The other disqualifying issue was celiac disease- a gluten/wheat intolerance. The thing is, I have never had a blood test to verify that I actually am celiac. I spoke too soon when giving DoDMERB medical information. It never occurred to me that the issue would be disqualifying. I identified with some of the symptoms of a celiac and found that not eating wheat stopped those symptoms. After trial and error with certain diets, my physician and I have recently determined I am only gluten sensitive. The reactions I get after eating bread or wheat are actually quite minimal- gas and bloating. There is no pain or anything that would hold me back in the field. My doctor is in the process of writing a letter clearing me of the wrongful diagnosis. I have heard from several military members and recruiters that there are waivers for everything. I've spoken with with a Marine recruiter who has seen someone with spinal fusion similar to mine get a waiver so I know it's possible! Has anyone out there experienced the waivering process like this? -Cherileigh, FL

content: When I was 17, I had my R ring finger nearly amputated. After several surgeries and PT, I joined the Army with no problem. I remember my recruiter saying that if I stayed in for retirement I would not get any comp for a prior injury. I did not care about that, (disability), I was 19 and at that time indestructible! I’ve never had a problem with it. I have full ROM, but very little feeling in it. Get Appt with Ortho and / or Neurology doctor see what they think. Break glass…in case of Emergency! Or, just wait till I get to the bottom of the bottle!

content: I've been in for 15 years and have a herniated disk and disk degeneration with bone spurs after my last deployment due to wearing so much equipment. I made it through, but I was in horrible pain by the time I finished my deployment. If you have back problems already, I doubt anyone will sign you up BECAUSE of the weight you are required to carry around. If by some chance they do let you in - and you aggrivate your injuries - you will get nothing and they will medically kick you out. Do not take further injury lightly. As you know - back pain is nothing to mess with!!! Plus, if you are in bad shape - then your buddies will have to pick up your slack (which is no fun).

content: Don't be surprised if you get turned down. Why? Right now times are tough. There are a lot of folks looking at the military that don't require waivers for medical conditions, etc. The recruiters are more likely to spend their time and effort on folks that take the least work to get in.
